exchanges.text: He comes forward himself, takes Juan's arm with thin but steady fingers, guides him to stand. It's a gesture of respect, if not warmth. The Fisherman's Ring catches the light from the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask how We fare. We shall tell you: We fare better this week than last. Do you know why?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He doesn't wait for an answer.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Because a king who completed the Reconquista has brought six hundred knights to Rome and knelt before Us asking how he might serve the Church. This is... not nothing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He settles into his seat now, gestures for Juan to take the chair opposite. It's placed facing the papal chair directly—a conversation between near-equals, not a supplicant before a throne. Cardinal Capranica shifts position, moving closer. The secretary's quill hovers over parchment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have heard reports from Basel. We know of Como. We know you signed declarations with the Emperor. We know you addressed the Council, that you spoke of reforms, that the Castilian delegation has become—influential among the moderate voices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A longer pause. Those deep-set eyes study Juan's face.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We also know that you have tried to walk a middle path. Between Us and the Council. Between authority and reform. Between those who would make the Pope a figurehead and those who would make reform impossible.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans back slightly, fingers steepled.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Middle paths are treacherous, beloved son. They satisfy no one and anger everyone. The French whisper that you are Rome's creature. Rome wonders if you have been seduced by Basel's promises. You cannot serve two masters. Scripture is clear on this point.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fire crackles. Outside, Rome's bells mark the hour.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tell Us—do you still believe such a path is possible? Or has Basel taught you otherwise?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There are many different ways you can look at our church, not just as a divide between papal and council parties. You can also divide the church in terms of culture, such as the french, Iberian, German... There are those of rigorous faith and those more lenient. The church is as diverse as it is enormous. And it is my firm belief that we should unite in one single church and there should be a place for almost everyone. Frenc, Germans, rigorous, and lenient, all aspects of our faith that indicate that men are different from one of another. How we can achieve this, that is indeed the difficult middle path you mentioned. I have often thought back to our first meeting where you expressed the desire to reform the church. Im sure you have heard of paralell legislation and how this principle will allow reform to proceed without papal authority bowing down to the council. Basel has passed reforms, has our holiness have had time to review these decrees?

roll.outcome: Cautious Interest: Eugenius softens slightly, acknowledges Juan's completed Reconquista and arrival with knights, but probes his loyalty regarding Basel and middle path strategy.

encounters.recap: Juan kneels before Pope Eugenius asking how he might serve the Church after visiting Basel. The Pope shows cautious interest, acknowledging Juan's credentials but questioning his middle path strategy between papal and conciliar authority, ultimately challenging whether such a position is sustainable.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Parallel legislation. We have heard this term. From Basel. From the Emperor's letters. Now from you. You propose that We independently promulgate the same reforms that Basel has passed. That We claim them as Our own initiative rather than Council decree. That both authorities take credit, neither bows to the other. A elegant solution. On parchment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back, silhouetted against the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But tell Us, beloved son—if Basel passes a decree in September, and We pass the identical decree in April, who does Christendom believe truly authored the reform? The Council that acted first? Or the Pope who... followed? You ask if We have reviewed Basel's decrees. We have. Pluralism. Annates. Concubinage. Much of it is... reasonable. Even necessary. But how reform comes matters as much as what reform comes. If We simply sign what Basel has already written, We become a notary. A clerk who stamps documents prepared by others. Explain to Us how this is not surrender with better rhetoric.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The council has been unexpectedly productive. They have been able to agree on many subjects, much more so than I thought possible. Since the council passed many reforms already, if Rome passes the same reforms as well, the impression can indeed be made that Rome follows Basel. I must confess that I did not expect this. I had hoped that both entities could pass some reforms and could demonstrate that they could both sign each other's decrees. I agree with you that the reforms themselves are good. Looking at just the church and how it should be reformed, we should be signing them today. If your holiness agrees with me, but only has reservations about authority, we should now seek a way to reform the church while maintaining papal authority.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You confess you did not expect this. That Basel moved faster than you anticipated. We find your honesty... refreshing. Most who come before Us have answers for everything. You admit to miscalculation. You say We should seek a way to reform while maintaining papal authority. Yes. Obviously. But how? You speak in principles. We must act in specifics. Basel has passed decrees on pluralism, on annates, on concubinage. The ink is dry. The documents are being copied and sent across Christendom as we speak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leans forward.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If We sign identical decrees tomorrow, We follow. If We refuse to sign, We appear to oppose reform itself—which We do not. If We modify the decrees, We invite endless negotiation about which version holds force. Basel will claim theirs is superior because the Council is superior. We will claim Ours. Christendom will have two sets of laws and obey neither. You have come with 600 knights, with letters from the Emperor, with the moral weight of Granada behind you. You have not come empty-handed, and you have not come without purpose. So speak plainly, King Juan. What specifically do you propose We do? And what do you want in return for helping Us do it?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What we could do, is we sign the reforms everyone agrees on. Pluralism for example and concubinage, maybe some other decrees as well. And then immediately and without delay start enforcing these decrees. Start enforcing the concubinage decree in France for example and demand the French to cooperate and in effect bow down to your authority. The council has already passed the decree so they have no other choice than to defer to your judgement. This creates equality and demonstrates Rome holds authority. Secondly, pass a decree yourself the council has not addressed. Choose a subject no-one can object to and request the council to pass the decree as well. If they don't it will make them look like extremists who use politics to advance their own positions. The more decrees are passed by both sides using this system, the more the council loses in significance. We can start sending Italian delegates as well until the council is simply not relevant anymore.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a sophisticated strategy to Pope Eugenius for resolving the Basel crisis through parallel legislation and strategic enforcement. While acknowledging that Basel moved faster than expected, Juan outlines a two-part plan: first, Rome should adopt and actively enforce Basel's uncontroversial reforms to demonstrate papal authority in implementation; second, Rome should initiate new reforms that Basel must then follow, gradually diminishing the Council's relevance through strategic maneuvering and Italian delegate participation.

And you have not yet mentioned what Castile receives in return. We have learned, beloved son, that gifts freely offered are never free. The Emperor offered mediation and produced Como—which bound Us to nothing and gave Basel legitimacy. Now you offer strategy. What is the price beneath the wrapping? Speak it plainly, or We shall assume the worst.

roll.outcome: Suspicious Probing - Pope demands clarification on Juan's true intentions and price

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a sophisticated strategy to outmaneuver Basel: sign agreed reforms immediately, enforce them aggressively to demonstrate papal authority, then issue papal decrees forcing Basel to follow. Pope Eugenius responds with deep suspicion, demanding to know Juan's true price and comparing him to the Emperor's failed mediation at Como.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius listens. His face remains impassive throughout—no nods of agreement, no sharpening of interest. When Juan finishes, the Pope does not respond to the strategy at all. Instead, silence stretches.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You propose that We sign decrees. Enforce them across hostile territories—France, no less. Issue counter-decrees. Flood Basel with Italian delegates until the Council withers. A comprehensive campaign. Years of effort. Substantial resources. Political capital spent across Christendom. And you have not yet mentioned what Castile receives in return.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have learned, beloved son, that gifts freely offered are never free. The Emperor offered mediation at Como. He spoke of cooperation, of bridges between Rome and Basel, of shared purpose. And what did Como produce? A declaration that bound Us to nothing and gave Basel legitimacy to continue. Words. Paper. Nothing that cost Sigismund anything.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Now you come. With knights. With letters. With strategies that sound reasonable and cost you nothing to propose. You speak of enforcing decrees in France—but Castilian swords will not march on Paris. You speak of flooding Basel with delegates—but Castile has already positioned itself as a moderate voice there, which serves your interests regardless of what We do. What is the price beneath the wrapping, King Juan? What does Castile want that you have not yet named? Constantinople support? We expected that. What else? Naples recognition for your ally Alfonso? Permanent administration of your Military Orders? A cardinal's hat for someone in your household? Speak it plainly. All of it. Or We shall assume the worst—that you seek to make the Pope of Rome dependent on Castilian strategy while appearing to serve the Church.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Father, I come before you as a christian king. Castille owes it's entire existance to Christianity and the church. In that case the fate of the church and Castille are intertwined. Crusades have formed my kingdoms and has given me and my fathers so much purpose. We would be nothing without our faith and we would have not been able to unite without the church. I seek no monetary support, no position for a bishop, no recognition of claims. The fact alone that there exists a strong and unified church is of enormous importance to me and my kingdom. But there is also another matter that makes me want a unified church father, and that reason is more personal. I have a strong personal belief that the church is of enormous benefit, not just to my kingdom but to any kingdom. Farmers being called to mass by church bells all across the lands fills my heart with joy. To know God is being praised, confessions are being taken. To know we all lift one another up to live fulfilling lives in service. It is all I want, what I am fighting for and strikes me in my very core. I dont need the church to endorse my crusade and aid me in my aid to Constantinople, I have already pledged the aid. But even I cannot defeat the Ottomans alone and I see no world where all christians unite to fight without a strong church.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises from his chair. For a moment he simply stands there, looking at Juan. Then he turns—not to the window, but to Cardinal Capranica.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Domenico. Leave Us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cardinal hesitates only a moment longer. Then he bows—deep, formal—and withdraws. The secretary gathers his parchment and quill with trembling hands, following without being told. The heavy door closes behind them. The Pope and the King are alone. Eugenius moves closer. Not to the window, not to his chair—to Juan. He stops an arm's length away, and when he speaks, his voice is barely above a whisper.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We are going to say something We have not said to anyone. Not to Our cardinals. Not to Our confessors. Not even in the silence of Our own prayers, because We feared God would hear and judge Us for it. We have been losing Our faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words seem to cost him something physical. His shoulders bow slightly, as if a weight has been lifted and a greater one placed in its stead.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Not in God. Never in God. But in the Church. In whether she can be saved. Whether she is worth saving. Basel calls Us corrupt. Perhaps they are right. The Camera is empty. The cardinals scheme—even the loyal ones scheme, they simply scheme in Our favor. Rome itself is held together with prayers and threats and the memory of what it once meant.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: For three years We have been told that We are a tyrant. An obstacle to reform. That the Church would flourish if only We would yield, or abdicate, or die. For three years We have defended the authority of Peter's throne, and We no longer remember if We defend it because it is sacred or because surrendering would mean admitting they were right about Us. And then you come. Speaking of church bells. Of farmers gathering for Mass. Of confessions and purpose and the joy of knowing God is praised across the land. Do you know how long it has been since anyone spoke to Us of why the Church exists? Everyone speaks of what she controls. What she costs. What she forbids. No one speaks of what she gives.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He grips Juan's arm—not as Pope to supplicant, but as a man reaching for something solid in dark water.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not know if you are the answer to Our prayers or the most dangerous man We have ever met. We do not know if this is Providence or the most sophisticated manipulation ever attempted against the Holy See. We do not care. Tell Us everything, King Juan. Constantinople. The Ottomans. The reforms. What you need, what you fear, what you hope to build. We are listening—not as Pope to king, not as authority to supplicant—but as one Christian to another. As a man who has forgotten why he became a priest, speaking to a man who seems to remember why he became a king.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He releases Juan's arm. Steps back. The mask of the papacy lies somewhere on the floor between them, and the man beneath stands exposed.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Help Us remember, Juan of Castile. Help Us believe the Church is worth saving. And We will give you whatever is in Our power to give.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But father! The church has always been worthy! We as men fail. We fear sometimes before we remember that stepping forward into the light is scary because it exposes us, shows everyone we are not perfect. But it also sets us free. The church itself is holy, it are the men who sin. We all know this and we fear that speaking this aloud, lets others think that the church sins as well. But this is not true. I would say we should sign all decrees passed by Basel and one of our own as well. And start enforcing them immediately. The scism must have drained the coffers of the camera, we should immediately start collecting again. I have no access to the camera itself, but I suspect that a decree properly enforced could actually increase the amount of income the camera recieves.

roll.outcome: Genuine Connection - The Pope reveals his deepest spiritual crisis, admits to losing faith in the Church, and opens himself completely to Juan's vision.

encounters.recap: Confronted about his true motives, Juan delivers an impassioned declaration of pure faith, speaking of church bells and farmers at Mass. The Pope initially remains skeptical, but after rolling 93 on the response table, experiences a profound emotional breakthrough. He dismisses all attendees, confesses he has been losing faith in the Church itself, and opens himself completely to Juan as one Christian to another, offering whatever aid is in his power.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Church is holy. Only men sin. Yes. Yes. We knew this once. Before We became the man everyone sins against and everyone blames for sin. You speak of signing all Basel's decrees. Enforcing them. Collecting revenues. Unifying Christendom under papal authority. We want this. God knows We want this. But We must speak of realities, even now.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The annates decree. Basel reduced papal taxation by three-quarters. Three-quarters, Juan. The Camera is already bleeding. If We sign that decree and enforce it, We enforce Our own impoverishment. And France. You speak of papal legates enforcing policy everywhere. The French have their Pragmatic Sanction—they already treat Our authority as advisory. Their bishops shelter behind royal protection.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Help Us understand how. How does enforcement increase revenue? How do We compel France without the power to compel? How do We sign Basel's decrees without appearing to surrender to Basel? We are asking as a partner now. Not testing you. Not doubting you. Simply... asking. Because We have dreamed of this unified Church you describe, and We need to know if it can be more than a dream.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then tell me how the french pragmatic sanction prevents us from collecting Rome's dues.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The French have long claimed what they call libertés gallicanes—Gallican liberties. The principle that the French church governs itself in temporal matters, that royal authority shields French clergy from Roman jurisdiction. In practice: when Rome demands payment from a French bishop, he appeals to his archbishop. The archbishop defers to the crown. The crown declares that French clergy pay taxes to the French king, not to foreign powers—and yes, they call Rome a foreign power when it suits them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Why should they pay tax to Rome in the first place? What do they recieve in return? For me and everyone in Iberia, the advantages are very apparent, but for the french? Not so much. Especially if these funds are being used for... excess and sin. And if they get no influence as well, I can understand why feel hesitant to pay. What is the money of the camera being used for?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We could give you the official accounting. The maintenance of the Papal States. The defense against Milan's condottieri. The salaries of the Curia—the secretaries, the notaries, the judges who hear appeals from across Christendom. The upkeep of St. Peter's. Charitable distributions. The papal household. We could also tell you the truth. The truth is that We do not fully know. The Camera has its own bureaucracy. Its own traditions. Funds flow through channels established centuries ago, and when We have asked for accountings, We receive documents so complex that three clerks working for a month could not untangle them.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: What We do know: cardinals live in palaces. They keep households of dozens—servants, secretaries, guards, cooks. They host banquets. They patronize artists. They maintain... companions. The Curia employs men whose positions were purchased, not earned—sinecures sold to fund some previous Pope's war or building project. And yes, there has been excess. There has been sin.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But father, this may be exactly what the Lord requires of us. We should ask ourselves if the current situation is something we actually want to change. Do we want a camera with finances that are so complicated that they obscure the real expenses. If we ask Jezus, I think we already know what the answer is going to be. If we have our purpose, than the rest just becomes work. We should pull out the camera into the light and find out what is really going on.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Last year I deposited an enormous treasury, gold reserved for future crusades. We can ask the camera right now if they can produce this treasury. There has been no crusade since so it should be intact, every penny of it. What do you think? Has the camera kept it locked away or have they found ways to dip into this pile of gold?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Three hundred and fifteen thousand florins. With complete accounting. Forty-seven pages documenting every expense of your Reconquista, every coin remaining. We remember. We were... moved by the gesture. A king who returns a treasury instead of keeping it. Who provides accounting instead of excuses. You ask if the Camera has kept it locked away. If every penny remains intact, waiting for the crusade it was meant to fund. We do not know.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Three years of crisis, Juan. Milan's armies threatening the Papal States. The Colonna demanding payment to keep peace in Rome itself. Basel draining Our authority and with it Our ability to collect. The cardinals requiring their... maintenance. We signed documents. Many documents. Authorizations for 'temporary transfers' to meet 'immediate needs' with 'full repayment upon resolution of current difficulties.' We told Ourselves it was necessary. That the crusade funds would be restored. That God would understand.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not know if your treasury is intact. We do not know how much remains. We have been afraid to ask. You propose we ask the Camera now. Pull them into the light. What happens, King Juan, if the answer is what We fear it is?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We already know the answer father. Maybe not the exact extent of it, but we know. I am not so concerned with the crusade coffers being drained. You as pope can act with authority to allocate these funds to wherever you like. But I am more concerned with a camera that seems to be bleeding money at an alarming rate. This is something we should adress immediately. I think there is a lot of popwer around the camera and the funds being allocated.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If you want, we can reform the camera together. I have done it before. I call it bringing down the hammer. Forge our kingdom and church as we believe it best in the image of our lord. This is the real work and it can be gracious and beautiful. It also gives purpose to us and those wanting a true church as well.

encounters.recap: In an emotional breakthrough, Pope Eugenius reveals his crisis of faith and admits the Vatican's financial corruption. He confesses that the papal treasury is mismanaged by an opaque bureaucracy, cardinals live in luxury, and Juan's crusade funds may have been diverted. Juan proposes joint reform of the Camera, offering to help 'bring down the hammer' on Vatican corruption and forge a renewed Church.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You propose we ask the Camera now. Pull them into the light. What happens, King Juan, if the answer is what We fear it is?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We already know the answer father. Maybe not the exact extent of it, but we know. I am not so concerned with the crusade coffers being drained. You as pope can act with authority to allocate these funds to wherever you like. But I am more concerned with a camera that seems to be bleeding money at an alarming rate. This is something we should address immediately. I think there is a lot of power around the camera and the funds being allocated. If these funds are being used to defend the church, no objection. But I suspect many men have been profiting from this situation enormously. If you want, we can reform the camera together. I have done it before. I call it bringing down the hammer. Forge our kingdom and church as we believe it best in the image of our lord. This is the real work and it can be gracious and beautiful. It also gives purpose to us and those wanting a true church as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Something shifts in Eugenius's expression. The fear doesn't disappear, but it is joined by something else—anger, perhaps, long suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You say we already know the answer. That the Camera has been bleeding money. That men have been profiting while the Church withers. Yes. We know. We have known, Juan of Castile. For three years We have known. We have watched cardinals build palaces while parishes crumble. We have signed 'temporary transfer' documents and pretended not to understand what they truly meant. We have told Ourselves We were too weak to act, too threatened from without to risk making enemies within. Perhaps We have been a coward. Perhaps survival has become an excuse for abdication. Perhaps We have confused prudence with paralysis.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You completed the Reconquista. Seven centuries of work finished in two years. You reformed your treasury—you say you have done this before. You did not wait for perfect conditions. You did not tell yourself the time was not right. You acted. Teach Us. Show Us how you brought down the hammer in Castile.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will need allies. There are honest men in the Curia—a few. Cardinals who have watched the corruption and despaired as We have despaired. We will need to find them, cultivate them, bring them into this... this hammer of yours. And We will need protection. Not soldiers in Rome. That would destroy Us faster than the corruption ever could. But backing. The knowledge—spread quietly through the right channels—that if certain powerful men move against Us, they move against Castile as well. Can you give Us this? Not troops, not gold—just the shadow of strength behind Us.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Father, you will find that when you walk the right path, much becomes possible. I can pledge all the crowns I command in your defence without reservation or hesitation. And I know that my fellow king and emperor of the holy roman empire feels the same way. This gives you all the power and military backing you would need to push through the reform. But father, have we now identified that you or not even the papacy opposes reforms. But rather the camera and corrupt cardinals are the real enemy? This is important.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius moves to the window, stands silhouetted against the pale March light, his thin shoulders rigid beneath the white robes.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask Us to say it plainly. To name the enemy. For three years We have told Ourselves the enemy was Basel. The Council. The conciliarists who would reduce the Pope to a figurehead. We have fought them. Resisted them. Spent every waking hour defending papal authority against their attacks. And all the while, the true rot was here. In Rome. In the Camera. In Our own household. The reformers at Basel—most of them—they do not hate the Church. They hate what the Church has become. They see cardinals living like princes while parishes lack priests. They see fees and taxes flowing to Rome and disappearing into... what? Banquets. Palaces. Courtesans. They are not wrong to be angry.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask if the Camera and corrupt cardinals are the real enemy. Yes. God help Us, yes. The men who have turned Peter's treasury into their personal wealth. The families who have treated the Curia as their inheritance. The officials who have made the Church's finances so opaque that even the Pope cannot trace where the money flows. Some of them elected Us. Some of them kept Us alive when the Colonna threatened. Some of them We have called friends. They will not surrender their corruption quietly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We know what we have to do. But we fear consequence if we do what we must. We may die. We may suffer. Any number of things can happen. And we can turn to scripture in these instances. What does the gospel preach when we can act righteously but have fears and doubts? What would any priest tell us in this situation? What would Jezus have done?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius freezes. The question strikes him like a physical blow. His mouth opens, closes. His hand falls away from Juan's arm. He stands there, the Pope of Rome, the Vicar of Christ—and a king has just asked him what scripture teaches about fear.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask Us— You ask the Pope what the Gospel preaches. What Jesus would do. We have spent three years hiding behind theology while forgetting the first lesson Christ ever taught. Be not afraid. Three hundred and sixty-five times in scripture. One for every day of the year, the scholars say. As if God knew we would need constant reminding. Fear not, for I am with you. I will strengthen you. I will help you. For God gave us not a spirit of fear, but of power and love and self-control.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: What would Jesus have done? He walked into the Temple and overturned the tables of the money-changers. He did not ask permission. He did not wait for perfect conditions. He did not worry that the Pharisees would call Him dangerous or the Romans would take notice. He saw corruption in His Father's house, and He drove it out. Any priest would tell Us what We already know. That faith without works is dead. That the shepherd who fears the wolf more than he loves the sheep is no shepherd at all.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You did not come here to teach Us scripture, King of Castile. You came to make Us remember what We already knew and were too frightened to act upon. Very well. We remember now. We will bring down the hammer. We will reform the Camera. We will drag the corruption into the light, whatever the cost. If they kill Us for it, then We will die as a Pope should die—defending Christ's Church, not cowering while others plunder her. Will you help Us begin? Today? Now? Before Our courage fails Us again?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The lord provides father. The lord provides. If we enact a powerful review of the camera and of church finances, this would create a decree impossible for Basel not to pass. Include wording about enforcement mechanisms that will allow you access into France. They will have no recourse at all. This will reform the church and restore Rome's authority extremely powerfully. This is the way. But first. Security. Are we safe where we are right now? If they learn about our intent, can they move to threaten or capture us?

roll.outcome: Growing Resolve - Eugenius embraces the challenge, finding strength through spiritual conviction and Juan's backing

encounters.recap: Juan proposes joint reform of the papal Camera to address massive financial corruption. After initial fear, Pope Eugenius finds resolve through scriptural reflection, acknowledging that corrupt cardinals—not Basel—are the true enemy of the Church. He agrees to immediate action with Castilian backing, transforming from defensive survivor to reforming Pope ready to 'bring down the hammer' on corruption.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question cuts through Eugenius's rising fervor like cold water. He stops. Blinks. The fire in his eyes dims—not extinguished, but banked by sudden practical fear. He looks around the chamber as if seeing it for the first time. The tapestries on the walls. The door through which Capranica and the secretary departed. The windows overlooking Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Safe. This chamber is... reasonably secure. We use it for private audiences precisely because it has fewer servants' passages than the formal halls. But— Cardinal Capranica heard much before We dismissed him. He is loyal, We believe. One of the few. But his household talks to other households. And the secretary... The secretary is Camera-appointed. Not Ours. He reports to Cardinal Condulmer—Our cousin, yes, but also a man with his own interests in how Camera funds flow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to pace, but tightly now, controlled.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If we speak of this openly—if We summon Camera officials and demand accountings without preparation—word will spread within hours. The men who have profited will know before sunset. They have had decades to build their networks. We have had three years of... of not looking too closely. Your knights. The 591 at their billets. How quickly could they reach the Vatican if summoned?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A pause.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not ask because We intend violence. We ask because We need to know what options exist if... Capranica. We must speak with him. Carefully. He has argued for reform before—quietly, knowing We were not ready to hear it. If he can be trusted... And there are others. Cardinal Albergati. Perhaps Bishop Parentucelli in the Curia. Men who have whispered their disgust to Us in private moments.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But you are right to ask about security first. We have been a fool once today already—letting emotion carry Us forward without thought. Before We bring down any hammers, We must know who holds the handles of the ones that might fall on Us. What would you advise, King Juan? You have done this before. When you moved against corruption in Castile—how did you protect yourself in those first critical hours?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My situation was a bit different. I want on pilgrimage and it suited my situation well. My knights are at your disposal and can summon them right now if we want. What about the men in your palace? Are they loyal to you, or loyal to someone else?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius's face goes very still. It is the stillness of a man confronting a question he has spent three years avoiding. He does not answer immediately. Instead, he moves to the door—not to open it, but to press his ear against it for a moment. Listening. Then he returns, closer to Juan than before, his voice barely a breath.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Papal Guard. Two hundred men. Their captain is... We appointed him Ourselves. Giacomo Pallavicini. Genoese. He owes nothing to the Roman families. We believe—Believe. Not know. We believe he is loyal. The household servants. Perhaps sixty. Most were here before Us. They served Martin V, Gregory XII before him—passed down like furniture from Pope to Pope. We know their faces. We do not know their hearts. Some certainly report to cardinals. The Colonna have eyes everywhere in Rome—it would be strange if they had none in the Vatican itself. The Orsini as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the window, glances out as if checking for watchers, then turns back.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The secretaries. The notaries. The Camera officials who handle documents, who control access, who know which doors are locked and which are open. These We did not appoint. These came with the office. They have served the Camera longer than any Pope has sat on Peter's throne. Their loyalty is to the institution—and the institution has been captured by the men who profit from it. You ask if they are loyal to Us or to someone else. The honest answer: We do not know. We have never tested them. We have never dared to test them, because testing them would reveal Our suspicions, and revealing Our suspicions would— Would make Us vulnerable. As We are now. As We have made Ourselves by speaking so freely with you.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If word of this conversation reaches the wrong ears before we are ready to act... if they learn that the Pope intends to audit the Camera, to demand accountings, to drag corruption into the light... Your knights. You say they are at Our disposal. How many would it take to secure this palace? Not to hold it against an army—just to ensure that no one leaves to carry messages until We are ready. An hour. Perhaps two. Long enough to summon the men We trust and dismiss the ones We do not.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I could summon all my knights here and expel those we do not trust. It provides us safety on our person. I will have to move in my household as well. I cannot protect them otherwise. But in my experience, it is extremely important that we publicly and openly announce what we plan to do. Drag into the light that which was in darkness. This will create new enemies, but will create even more allies as well. Personally, I usually give a speech before thousands. But that is me. You can do the same or declare your intentions in another way that is more aligned with your personality. Either way, we must say to the world: Here we are. And we are not afraid. Lets think strategically. If we declare all existing camera arrangements null and void and will build up papal finances from the ground up, what would our enemies do first? Will they secure the camera and it's treasury itself? Will they raise armies? What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius begins to pace again—but differently now. This is not the restless movement of fear. This is a man thinking, drawing on decades of watching Rome's powerful families maneuver.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Camera's treasury. It is not a chest of gold sitting in a vault, Juan. It is... dispersed. Claims. Debts owed. Revenues promised from benefices across Christendom. Letters of credit held by Florentine and Venetian banks. The actual coin in Rome at any moment is perhaps— Perhaps fifty thousand florins? Less? We do not know precisely. That is part of the problem.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops by the window, staring out but not seeing.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If we announce our intentions publicly, what would they do first? The documents. They would secure the documents before anything else. The ledgers. The account books. The records of who received what and when and why. Without those, we cannot prove corruption—we can only allege it. And allegations against cardinals without proof... That is how Popes get called tyrants. That is how Basel gains ammunition.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He resumes pacing.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The treasury itself—what coin exists—yes, they would move it. Quietly. Into private accounts, family holdings, anywhere beyond Our reach. By the time We sent men to secure it, the vaults would hold nothing but dust and excuses. Armies? No. Not immediately. The Roman families keep retainers, not armies. The Colonna perhaps two thousand men scattered across their holdings. The Orsini fewer. They would not march on the Vatican—not openly. That would turn all Christendom against them. But accidents happen to Popes, Juan. Fevers. Falls. Tainted food. A trusted servant who is not so trusted after all.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops, faces Juan directly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Their first move would be political, not military. They would send messengers to Basel within the hour—to Cardinal d'Allemand, to the French faction. Proof, they would say, that Eugenius has gone mad. That he has fallen under the control of a foreign king. That he threatens the liberty of the Church. They would wrap their corruption in the language of reform. They would make Us the tyrant for daring to ask where the money went.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves closer.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So. If we do this—if we truly do this—we must move faster than they can. Secure the documents before they can be destroyed or hidden. Control the messengers before word can reach Basel. And yes, announce our intentions publicly, loudly, so that all of Christendom hears our version before their whispers can poison the well. The Camera's offices are in the Apostolic Palace. A separate wing. Perhaps thirty clerks and officials work there during the day. At night... At night there are guards. Camera guards. Not Papal Guard—their own men.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your knights. How quickly can they truly be here? And when they arrive—are they prepared to secure a building full of documents against men who may resist? Not with swords necessarily, but with locked doors and burned ledgers and convenient fires?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: They can and will do so. My knights are at your disposal. But is it not possible to secure the camera itself and secure it with my knights? That would be maybe better then moving all the documents here. I can summon them here and let them swear an oath of allegiance to your person. They are devout and faithful christians and will keep their oath. This also creates legitimacy for what they are about to do. They will no longer be Castillian knights, it will be servants of the pope himself securing the interests of the church. And can the pope act on it's own accord? Or does papal authority depend on a vatican council of sorts? Can you theoretically summon a scribe and issue a papal decree by yourself?

encounters.recap: Juan and Pope Eugenius assess Vatican security vulnerabilities before launching financial reforms. The Pope reveals his precarious position—uncertain loyalties among household staff, Camera officials, and secretaries who may be compromised by Roman families. They strategize about securing documents and treasury, with Juan offering his knights to take oaths directly to the Pope for legitimacy in securing the Camera offices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius listens carefully. When Juan finishes, he does not answer immediately. His eyes flicker—calculating, assessing. The survival instincts of three years have not entirely given way to newfound resolve.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Secure the Camera building itself. Yes. That is... cleaner. The documents remain where they are. We control access. No one enters or leaves without Our permission. The Camera offices are not large. Perhaps your knights could hold them with—fifty men? A hundred? Enough to guard every door and window, enough to prevent accidents with candles and parchment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to a small writing desk in the corner of the chamber, touches it absently.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your knights swearing allegiance to Our person. This creates legitimacy, yes. They become servants of the Church, not a foreign army occupying the Vatican. But it also creates... questions. Six hundred Castilian knights, sworn to the Pope, holding the Camera. Cardinal d'Allemand will say We have sold the papacy to Spain. The French will claim—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops himself. Shakes his head.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: No. You are right. We cannot let fear of what enemies will say prevent Us from acting. They will say what they will say regardless. Better to act righteously and be slandered than to cower and be despised.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: As for papal authority— In principle, the Pope's authority is supreme and immediate. We can issue decrees, bulls, constitutions by Our own hand. The keys of Peter are Ours. No council, no consistory, no cardinal can legally prevent Us from exercising Our office. In principle. In practice... Major decrees are traditionally discussed in consistory—the assembly of cardinals. Not because We require their permission, but because issuing significant legislation without consultation appears tyrannical.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: However. There are precedents for urgent action. Motu proprio—by Our own initiative. When circumstances demand immediate response, the Pope may act alone and seek ratification afterward. We could summon a scribe. We could issue a decree establishing a commission to audit the Camera's finances. We could do it now, this hour, with only you as witness.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But such a decree, issued in secret, acted upon by foreign knights before the cardinals even know it exists... The legality would be unquestionable. The legitimacy—in the eyes of Christendom—that is another matter. We would need to announce it publicly almost immediately. Explain why urgency required extraordinary measures. Frame it as reform, not seizure.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You spoke of giving a speech before thousands. Of dragging into light what was in darkness. If We do this—secure the Camera tonight, issue the decree, present the world with accomplished fact—We will need to speak to Rome tomorrow. To the cardinals. To the people. We will need to explain Ourselves in a way that makes Us reformers, not tyrants.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have never been a man for speeches, Juan of Castile. We have survived by being quiet, by being cautious, by letting others speak while We listened. Will you help Us find the words?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I could help you write a speech or address that you can deliver in person to the public. But a question first. If you summon this assembly of cardinals. Is this essentially the enemy we have been speaking of? Will they oppose what we are discussing? How great is this group of cardinals?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius exhales slowly. The question has forced him to confront something he has been avoiding—taking a true inventory of his own princes of the Church.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The College of Cardinals. Twenty-four men currently hold the red hat. Some are here in Rome. Some at Basel. Some scattered across their dioceses or on various missions. In Rome, at this moment? Perhaps... fourteen. Fifteen.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Roman families first. Prospero Colonna. Giordano Orsini—yes, the same Orsini who was so cold to your Fray Hernando. His loyalty is to his family first, the Church second, and Us a distant third. These men have nephews and cousins throughout the Camera. They have built the system we seek to reform. They will oppose us absolutely.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The French. Cardinal Jean de Rochetaillée is here, watching everything for d'Allemand in Basel. Anything discussed in consistory reaches Basel within a week. He will frame any reform as tyranny, any audit as persecution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Then there are those who are simply... comfortable. Cardinals who have grown fat on the current arrangements. Who have benefices in three countries, households of fifty servants, palaces that rival princes. They may not actively conspire, but they will not welcome anyone examining how they live.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Allies. Capranica—you met him at Mass. He has whispered of reform before. Albergati, perhaps. He is old, devout, genuinely troubled by what he sees. Parentucelli is not yet a cardinal, but he is influential in the Curia and honest—We think. Three. Perhaps four. Out of twenty-four.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So yes. If We summon a formal consistory to discuss this, We are summoning the enemy to vote on their own destruction. They will delay. They will demand procedures, consultations, committees. They will bury reform in process until Our resolve weakens or Our health fails.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This is why We spoke of motu proprio. Of acting first and explaining after. The consistory exists to advise Us—not to command Us. We are not required to seek their permission. But acting without them, against them, while foreign soldiers hold the Camera...

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You see Our dilemma, King Juan. Move through proper channels, and the corrupt cardinals will strangle reform in their cradle. Move around them, and We hand Basel exactly the evidence they need to call Us a tyrant controlled by Spain. How did you manage this in Castile? Your nobles, your councils—how did you reform without giving your enemies the weapons to destroy you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Being right. Being on the side of good is the most powerful weapon there is father. Do not be afraid to wield it. We should write our decree in secret. And then summon as large an audience as we can and announce this decree under motu proprio. Combine it with signing the Basel reforms on pluralism and concubinage and the reform of the annates as well. We ask for the Basel council to pass the Camera reforms as well in the same way as we have affirmed their legislation regarding pluralism and the others. The council will pass these reforms. Secondly, we send out correspondence to christian monarchs asking for support against anyone moving against the pope and the reforms he is justly seeking. Castile, Aragon, Naples, Portugal and the holy roman empire will do so I think. Then, we replace my men with your own Italian loyal soldiers. Men who we can select and vet ourselves. And we start to expose, reform and gain control of the camera. Using just honest and good men to do so.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius listens intently, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. As Juan speaks, something shifts in his posture—the hunched wariness of a cornered man slowly giving way to something more upright. More like a Pope.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The structure is sound. Write in secret. Announce publicly. Combine our Camera reform with signing Basel's decrees—yes, this is clever. It makes Us appear as a reforming Pope, not a desperate one. It forces Basel to either support Us or reveal themselves as hypocrites who want reform only when it weakens Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Castile. Aragón. Naples. Portugal. The Empire. You believe these crowns will support Us. Perhaps you are right. Sigismund owes Us nothing, but he fears Basel more than he fears a strong Pope. Alfonso wants Naples recognized. Portugal follows where Castile leads. But you did not name France.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The French crown will not support this. They benefit from a weak papacy. They shelter their clergy behind the Pragmatic Sanction. Their cardinals lead the radical faction at Basel. When We announce these reforms, when We sign Basel's decrees and demand the Council pass Ours—France will see it as a threat. Not to corruption, but to French influence over the Church.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And the annates. You include the annates reform in what We should sign. Do you understand what that decree does? It reduces papal revenues from benefices by three-quarters. The Camera is already bleeding. If We sign that decree and enforce it honestly— How do We pay for anything? The Papal Guard. The Curia. The maintenance of the Papal States. How do We even pay for the loyal Italian soldiers you speak of replacing your knights with?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And these loyal Italians. Where do they come from? The Roman families control most of the armed men in the city. The Papal Guard is small—two hundred men—and even there, We cannot vouch for every soldier. If We dismiss your knights before we have trustworthy replacements... We would be defenseless at the moment of greatest danger.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We are not refusing, King Juan. We are asking you to think through these questions with Us. You have done this before—you know that the devil lives in the details. The annates. France. The soldiers. These are the rocks upon which this plan could founder. How do We navigate them?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The annates are not the problem. The camera is bleeding funds because they are incorrectly allocated. Not because they do not collect enough. Even if we double the annates and every church in christianity pays this amount, we would be in the same situation. These cardinals will continue to feed on the camera. As long as we do not address this problem, we will never have enough money. We have fifty thousand florins in cash. This should be enough to consolidate your power base here. Are you telling me the annates in the Basel decree are not enough to cover the scribes and other just costs the papacy has?

The Pope reveals the cardinals' factions—only 3-4 allies among 24, with Roman families and French cardinals as primary opponents. Juan argues that corruption, not revenue shortfalls, is the real financial problem, proposing to use his 50,000 florins to consolidate papal power.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius opens his mouth to respond—then closes it. He stands very still for a long moment. The sharpness in his eyes fades, replaced by something more uncomfortable. The look of a man who has just been caught in his own deflection.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are right. We raised the annates as an objection because... because it was easier than facing the true question. The truth is We do not know what legitimate papal expenses actually are. We do not know what it costs to run the Curia honestly, because the Curia has not been run honestly in living memory.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: They give Us reports. The Camera officials. Beautiful documents, detailed ledgers, impressive numbers. And We sign them and We do not ask questions because— Because asking questions would reveal how little We understand. How completely they have kept Us in darkness about Our own treasury.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Fifty thousand florins. You say it should be enough to consolidate power. Perhaps you are right. We do not know. We do not know what the Papal Guard truly costs, what the scribes and notaries require, what is necessary and what is excess. This is the depth of Our failure, Juan. We have been Pope for three years and We cannot tell you what it costs to be Pope.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The cardinals. Their palaces. Their households. Their banquets and mistresses and armies of servants. These are not legitimate expenses. These are parasites feeding on the body of the Church. You are right—even if We doubled revenues, they would simply take more.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So. The annates are not the problem. The allocation is the problem. The men who control the allocation are the problem. And We have been using their objections as Our own, because We were too frightened to see clearly. What of France, then? This objection We will not surrender so easily. The French crown will oppose us. Their cardinals will carry word to Basel. How do we prevent them from poisoning this reform before it can take root?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If we pass these reforms and our own decree reforming the camera, it will pass in Basel. France cannot choose to then ignore these decrees without a massive loss of face. They have been proposing the authority of Basel. If they invalidate Rome's decree after it has been affirmed by Basel, it invalidates their entire position. They would alienate themselves. And honestly, I think most of the french delegates would be on our side.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If France chooses to oppose Rome in regards to annates, by what authority? They can delay, but after Basel approves our reform, they will have no real power. It may take some years, but in the end, they should be paying like everybody else. Especially if you grant the French king attention and good relations. France is a very powerful kingdom. Maybe the most powerful in christianity and it is only natural we treat them as such. Ally yourself to the French king. And you will find that having an ally may work wonders.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The logic is sound. If Basel affirms Our decree on the Camera, the French cannot reject it without rejecting conciliar authority itself. They would be arguing that councils are supreme only when they agree with France. Even d'Allemand would struggle to make that case with a straight face.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But you speak of allying with the French king. Charles VII sits on a throne We helped him keep. We recognized his coronation when the English called him a bastard and a pretender. And how has he repaid Us? With the Pragmatic Sanction. With bishops who ignore Our legates. With cardinals who work to make Us a figurehead.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have tried to treat France as the great power it is. We have been rebuffed. Ignored. Treated as an obstacle to French ambitions rather than a partner. You make it sound simple—ally with the French king. But Charles listens to his counselors, and his counselors benefit from a weak papacy. Why would he choose friendship with Rome when enmity costs him nothing?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are King of Castile. You have dealt with monarchs, negotiated alliances, balanced powers against one another. What does France want that We could offer? What would make Charles VII see value in a strong Pope rather than a weak one? And—speak frankly—what does Castile's relationship with France look like? Are you enemies? Rivals? Could you serve as... intermediary? Or would French suspicion of Spanish influence make Our situation worse?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! I must confess I do not concern myself much with French politics. I was not informed about your recent relations with the French and their betrayal of trust. France will do to an extent what it will. They can in theory install a French anti-pope at any time. But the French clergymen all know they are part of the catholic church. If a just and fair decree has been passed, most will follow it. Do not underestimate this. If they indeed have a tradition of not paying Rome, it may take some time to reverse this. But I believe in time, it will. Make any future involvement with them conditional of recognizing these decrees. Kings always need papal recognition sooner or later. And what you are asking is not unreasonable.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You do not concern yourself much with French politics. Perhaps that is wisdom. We have spent three years concerning Ourselves with French politics, and what has it gained Us? Sleepless nights and a cardinal who reports Our every word to Basel.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are right, of course. French clergymen know they are Catholic. They confess. They celebrate Mass. They look to Rome for dispensations and appeals and the thousand small matters that require papal authority. They may resent paying, but they cannot pretend We do not exist. Not forever.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So. We do not solve France today. We act justly, We pass Our reforms, We let Basel affirm them—and We trust that time and pressure will do what argument cannot. This is... acceptable. We have spent too long trying to solve every problem before taking any step. Perhaps that is how one remains frozen forever.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Then let Us speak of what We do control. Here. Now. Tonight. First. The decree. We must write it before We leave this room. You and We, together. The language must be precise—establishing a commission to audit the Camera's finances, with authority to examine all records, question all officials, and report directly to Us.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Second. Your knights. When do they move? We must secure the Camera offices before word spreads of what We intend. Tonight? Tomorrow at dawn? The timing must be exact. Third. The announcement. You spoke of addressing thousands. We must decide—where? When? St. Peter's Square? The Basilica itself? And what do We say to make Rome understand this is reform, not tyranny?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Fourth. The letters to Christian monarchs. These must go out simultaneously with the announcement—or even before. Castile, Aragón, Portugal, the Empire. We must have their support publicly declared before Our enemies can frame the narrative.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have talked enough, King Juan. Talked until We have nearly lost Our nerve three times over. Let Us begin. What words should this decree contain?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then it is time to expand the circle we have. We need scribes we can trust. And maybe Capranica if we choose to trust him. Do you think we can?

encounters.recap: Juan confronts Pope Eugenius about the real financial crisis—not insufficient annates but corrupt allocation by parasitic cardinals. The Pope admits his ignorance about true papal costs and agrees to immediate action: drafting a Camera audit decree, securing offices with Juan's knights, making public announcements, and writing to Christian monarchs for support.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius pauses. The question is simple, but his answer is not. He moves to the door—not to open it, but to stand near it, as if Capranica might somehow hear through the heavy wood.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Domenico Capranica. He has served the Church for thirty years. He was denied his cardinal's hat by Martin V—a political slight, nothing to do with his character—and We restored it to him when We became Pope. He has reason to be grateful.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: He has spoken to Us of reform. Quietly. In private moments when no one else could hear. He has expressed... frustration with what he sees. The excess. The corruption. The way the Camera operates beyond anyone's true control. These conversations felt genuine. But—

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But We have learned that men say many things in private that they do not mean when circumstances change. Capranica has ambitions. He is not a young man, but he is not old either. He may hope to sit in this chair someday. If he believes Our reform will succeed, he will support it—perhaps genuinely, perhaps because he wishes to be seen as a reformer when the next conclave comes. If he believes it will fail...

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You met him. At Mass. He made himself visible to you deliberately—that was not accident. He sent your queen a careful, noncommittal message. What was your impression? You have dealt with men like this before. Cardinals, nobles, counselors who say the right things and wait to see which way the wind blows.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Can we trust him enough to bring him into this room tonight? Or do we write our decree alone and present him with accomplished fact?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Are there other cardinals or bishops we can trust more?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius is quiet for a moment. Then he moves to the window, staring out at Rome as he speaks.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cardinal Niccolò Albergati. Carthusian. Old now—nearly seventy. He has lived simply his entire life. No palace, no great household, no mistresses or nephews enriching themselves on Church funds. He has been troubled by the corruption for years. We have seen it in his face during consistory—the way he looks away when certain expenditures are approved. He is genuinely devout.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But he is old, Juan. And cautious by nature. The Carthusians are contemplatives, not warriors. Albergati has survived by being agreeable, by not making enemies. If We bring him into this room and tell him We intend to bring down the hammer on the Camera tonight—he might support Us in prayer. We do not know if he would support Us in action.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso Parentucelli. Not a cardinal—not yet—but influential. He serves as secretary to Albergati, in fact. Younger. Brilliant. A scholar who came from nothing and rose through merit alone. He has no family connections to the Roman powers, no income beyond his salary, no reason to protect the current system.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have spoken with him privately. He burns with quiet fury at what he sees. The waste. The simony. The way talented men are passed over for nephews and favorites. If anyone in the Curia would embrace reform genuinely, it is Parentucelli. But he has no power of his own. No vote in consistory. No troops, no wealth, no family to call upon.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cardinal Guillaume d'Estouteville. French, yes, but not d'Allemand's creature. He has quarreled with the French faction over matters of procedure. He is ambitious—very ambitious—but his ambition runs toward being seen as a statesman, a builder, a man of consequence. He might support reform if he believed it would succeed and he could share the credit. But French... and ambitious. A dangerous combination.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So. Albergati is honest but old and timid. Parentucelli is trustworthy but powerless. D'Estouteville is capable but French and self-interested. Capranica is the most useful—connected, respected, energetic—but also the most opaque. We cannot read his true heart.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If We must choose one to bring into this room tonight, who would you choose? Or do We write this decree alone, just the two of Us, and trust no one until the hammer has already fallen?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Summon Parentucelli. Start with him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius nods slowly and moves to the door, opens it a crack. The corridor beyond is empty save for a single papal guard at the far end.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Find Tommaso Parentucelli. He will be in Cardinal Albergati's quarters, or in the library. Tell him the Holy Father requires his assistance with a matter of correspondence. Urgent. He is to come alone and speak to no one of the summons.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The guard departs. Eugenius closes the door and turns back to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It will take perhaps a quarter hour. Albergati's quarters are in the Apostolic Palace, not far. While we wait—we should consider what we tell him. How much. How quickly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Parentucelli is not a fool. He will know the moment he enters this room that something extraordinary is happening. A private audience with the Pope and the King of Castile, summoned in secret, told to speak to no one? He will be frightened. He will wonder if this is a test—if someone has accused him of disloyalty and he is being examined.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We must put him at ease quickly. And then—do we tell him everything? The Camera, the reform, the knights, the decree? Or do we reveal it piece by piece, watching his reactions? You have more experience with this than We do, King Juan. How do you take the measure of a man in such moments?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We tell him everything father. If he is of true heart, he needs to know everything. We need allies. And that starts by being clear to them and later the world about who we are. If he is the man you say he is, then we should have nothing to worry about.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: While we wait; tell me if an examination of the expenditure of the camera would take place, would it uncover corruption? Even corruption on the highest level?

They decide to summon Tommaso Parentucelli, a scholar-secretary known for his integrity and frustration with Church corruption, choosing transparency over caution in their approach to building their reform coalition.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius goes still. The question hangs in the air between them. Simple. Direct. And cutting to the heart of everything they have been discussing. He does not answer immediately. Instead, he rises, moves to the fire, stares into it.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Yes. An honest examination would uncover... much. The Camera has operated in shadow for decades. Perhaps longer. Every Pope since Avignon has relied on it, drawn from it, and chosen not to look too closely at how it functions.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cardinals have enriched their families. Offices have been sold. Revenues meant for the maintenance of churches have been diverted to palaces. Funds designated for charitable works have been... Reallocated. The crusade treasury you deposited—We told you We do not know how much remains. That is true. But We suspect. We suspect it has been touched, despite Our instructions.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You are asking whether an examination would uncover evidence against Us. Against the Pope himself. We have signed documents. Many documents. Authorizations for transfers, for expenditures, for payments We did not fully understand. We told Ourselves We were delegating to men who knew the Camera's workings better than We did.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Would an honest examination find that We knowingly stole from the Church? No. We have taken nothing for Ourselves. Our chambers are modest. Our household is small. We have no nephews growing fat on benefices, no mistresses draped in jewels. But would it find that We were negligent? That We signed what We should not have signed? That We failed in Our duty to guard the treasury of Peter? Yes. It would find that.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If We bring down this hammer, it may fall on Us as well. Not as a thief—but as a fool. A Pope who let himself be used. Is that a price worth paying? We believe it is. We must believe it is, or We cannot do what must be done.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It will father. And dont worry too much about this. If we pass reform it may for a moment seem like everything is against us, but soon, everyone will be on our side if we truly fight corruption. We could state for example that from this moment on, things will be different. From this moment on, we restart the camera with a clean set of obligations and income.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: A fresh start. No investigations into past sins. Simply... end the old arrangements and begin anew. This is... merciful. Perhaps wiser than We had considered. You are right that pursuing every corrupt cardinal would unite them against Us. They would have nothing to lose. Cornered animals fight hardest.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The crusade treasury. Your treasury, Juan. Three hundred and fifteen thousand florins you entrusted to the Church for sacred purpose. If We make a clean break, if We investigate nothing... We never learn where it went. We never recover what was taken. Can you accept this?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets ask him as well. And if you were wondering if I can live with the treasury going to some palace of a cardinal? If me forgiving him means a better, reformed and united church no price is too high. Jezus learns us to turn the other cheek. What's done is done, now lets turn ourselves to the future. Parentucelli, come in.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The man who enters is perhaps forty, slight of build, with the pale complexion of one who spends his days among books and manuscripts. His dark hair is thinning at the temples. His robes are plain—no silk, no embroidery, the simple black of a working cleric. But his eyes are sharp, quick, taking in the room in a single glance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Tommaso Parentucelli drops to his knees immediately. He does not look up. He does not look at Juan. Protocol demands he acknowledge only the Pope until given leave to do otherwise.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father. Your Holiness summoned me.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rise, Tommaso. Close the door behind you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When he turns back, his face is carefully neutral—but his hands, clasped before him, grip each other tightly. He has noticed the absence of scribes. The absence of witnesses. The presence of a foreign king in what should be a private papal chamber. He knows something extraordinary is happening. He does not know if it is opportunity or danger.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: How may I serve Your Holiness?

encounters.recap: Juan and Pope Eugenius discuss their reform strategy before Parentucelli's arrival. The Pope confesses that an honest audit of the Camera would reveal extensive corruption, possibly implicating him through negligence. Juan advocates for a merciful approach—a fresh start without investigating past corruption, even accepting the loss of his crusade treasury for the greater good of church unity. They summon Parentucelli to join their reform alliance.
